00014 #include <GeographicLib/Constants.hpp>

00017 namespace GeographicLib {
00018 
00019   /**
00020    * \brief The normal gravity of the earth
00021    *
00022    * "Normal" gravity refers to an idealization of the earth which is modeled
00023    * as an rotating ellipsoid.  The eccentricity of the ellipsoid, the rotation
00024    * speed, and the distribution of mass within the ellipsoid are such that the
00025    * surface of the ellipsoid is a surface of constant potential (gravitational
00026    * plus centrifugal).  The acceleration due to gravity is therefore
00027    * perpendicular to the surface of the ellipsoid.
00028    *
00029    * There is a closed solution to this problem which is implemented here.
00030    * Series "approximations" are only used to evaluate certain combinations of
00031    * elementary functions where use of the closed expression results in a loss
00032    * of accuracy for small arguments due to cancellation of the two leading
00033    * terms.  However these series include sufficient terms to give full machine
00034    * precision.
00035    *
00036    * Definitions:
00037    * - <i>V</i><sub>0</sub>, the gravitational contribution to the normal
00038    *   potential;
00039    * - \e Phi, the rotational contribution to the normal potential;
00040    * - \e U = <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> + \e Phi, the total
00041    *   potential;
00042    * - <b>Gamma</b> = <b>grad</b> <i>V</i><sub>0</sub>, the acceleration due to
00043    *   mass of the earth;
00044    * - <b>f</b> = <b>grad</b> \e Phi, the centrifugal acceleration;
00045    * - <b>gamma</b> = <b>grad</b> \e U = <b>Gamma</b> + <b>f</b>, the normal
00046    *   acceleration;
00047    * - \e X, \e Y, \e Z, geocentric coordinates;
00048    * - \e x, \e y, \e z, local cartesian coordinates used to denote the east,
00049    *   north and up directions.
00050    *
00051    * References:
00052    * - W. A. Heiskanen and H. Moritz, Physical Geodesy (Freeman, San
00053    *   Francisco, 1967), Secs. 1-19, 2-7, 2-8 (2-9, 2-10), 6-2 (6-3).
00054    * - H. Moritz, Geodetic Reference System 1980, J. Geod. 54(3), 395-405
00055    *   (1980) http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/BF02521480
00056    **********************************************************************/
00057 
00058   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT NormalGravity {
00059   private:
00060     static const int maxit_ = 10;
00061     typedef Math::real real;
00062     friend class GravityModel;
00063     real _a, _GM, _omega, _f, _J2, _omega2, _aomega2;
00064     real _e2, _ep2, _b, _E, _U0, _gammae, _gammap, _q0, _m, _k, _fstar;
00065     Geocentric _earth;
00066     static Math::real qf(real ep2) throw();
00067     static Math::real qpf(real ep2) throw();
00068     Math::real Jn(int n) const throw();
00069   public:
00070 
00071     /** \name Setting up the normal gravity
00072      **********************************************************************/
00073     ///@{
00074     /**
00075      * Constructor for the normal gravity.
00076      *
00077      * @param[in] a equatorial radius (meters).
00078      * @param[in] GM mass constant of the ellipsoid
00079      *   (meters<sup>3</sup>/seconds<sup>2</sup>); this is the product of \e G
00080      *   the gravitational constant and \e M the mass of the earth (usually
00081      *   including the mass of the earth's atmosphere).
00082      * @param[in] omega the angular velocity (rad s<sup>-1</sup>).
00083      * @param[in] f the flattening of the ellipsoid.
00084      * @param[in] J2 dynamical form factor.
00085      *
00086      * Exactly one of \e f and \e J2 should be positive and this will be used
00087      * to define the ellipsoid.  The shape of the ellipsoid can be given in one
00088      * of two ways:
00089      * - geometrically, the ellipsoid is defined by the flattening \e f =
00090      *   (\e a - \e b) / \e a, where \e a and \e b are the equatorial radius
00091      *   and the polar semi-axis.
00092      * - physically, the ellipsoid is defined by the dynamical form factor
00093      *   <i>J</i><sub>2</sub> = (\e C - \e A) / <i>Ma</i><sup>2</sup>, where \e
00094      *   A and \e C are the equatorial and polar moments of inertia and \e M is
00095      *   the mass of the earth.
00096      **********************************************************************/
00097     NormalGravity(real a, real GM, real omega, real f, real J2);
00098 
00099     /**
00100      * A default constructor for the normal gravity.  This sets up an
00101      * uninitialized object and is used by GravityModel which constructs this
00102      * object before it has read in the parameters for the reference ellipsoid.
00103      **********************************************************************/
00104     NormalGravity() : _a(-1) {}
00105     ///@}
00106 
00107     /** \name Compute the gravity
00108      **********************************************************************/
00109     ///@{
00110     /**
00111      * Evaluate the gravity on the surface of the ellipsoid.
00112      *
00113      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00114      * @return \e gamma the acceleration due to gravity, positive downwards
00115      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00116      *
00117      * Due to the axial symmetry of the ellipsoid, the result is independent of
00118      * the value of the longitude.  This acceleration is perpendicular to the
00119      * surface of the ellipsoid.  It includes the effects of the earth's
00120      * rotation.
00121      **********************************************************************/
00122     Math::real SurfaceGravity(real lat) const throw();
00123 
00124     /**
00125      * Evaluate the gravity at an arbitrary point above (or below) the
00126      * ellipsoid.
00127      *
00128      * @param[in] lat the geographic latitude (degrees).
00129      * @param[in] h the height above the ellipsoid (meters).
00130      * @param[out] gammay the northerly component of the acceleration
00131      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00132      * @param[out] gammaz the upward component of the acceleration
00133      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>); this is usually negative.
00134      * @return \e U the corresponding normal potential.
00135      *
00136      * Due to the axial symmetry of the ellipsoid, the result is independent of
00137      * the value of the longitude and the easterly component of the
00138      * acceleration vanishes, \e gammax = 0.  The function includes the effects
00139      * of the earth's rotation.  When \e h = 0, this function gives \e gammay =
00140      * 0 and the returned value matches that of NormalGravity::SurfaceGravity.
00141      **********************************************************************/
00142     Math::real Gravity(real lat, real h, real& gammay, real& gammaz)
00143       const throw();
00144 
00145     /**
00146      * Evaluate the components of the acceleration due to gravity and the
00147      * centrifugal acceleration in geocentric coordinates.
00148      *
00149      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00150      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00151      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00152      * @param[out] gammaX the \e X component of the acceleration
00153      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00154      * @param[out] gammaY the \e Y component of the acceleration
00155      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00156      * @param[out] gammaZ the \e Z component of the acceleration
00157      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00158      * @return \e U = <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> + \e Phi the sum of the
00159      *   gravitational and centrifugal potentials
00160      *   (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00161      *
00162      * The acceleration given by <b>gamma</b> = <b>grad</b> \e U = <b>grad</b>
00163      * <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> + <b>grad</b> \e Phi = <b>Gamma</b> + <b>f</b>.
00164      **********************************************************************/
00165     Math::real U(real X, real Y, real Z,
00166                  real& gammaX, real& gammaY, real& gammaZ) const throw();
00167 
00168     /**
00169      * Evaluate the components of the acceleration due to gravity alone in
00170      * geocentric coordinates.
00171      *
00172      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00173      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00174      * @param[in] Z geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00175      * @param[out] GammaX the \e X component of the acceleration due to gravity
00176      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00177      * @param[out] GammaY the \e Y component of the acceleration due to gravity
00178      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00179      * @param[out] GammaZ the \e Z component of the acceleration due to gravity
00180      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00181      * @return <i>V</i><sub>0</sub> the gravitational potential
00182      *   (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00183      *
00184      * This function excludes the centrifugal acceleration and is appropriate
00185      * to use for space applications.  In terrestrial applications, the
00186      * function NormalGravity::U (which includes this effect) should usually be
00187      * used.
00188      **********************************************************************/
00189     Math::real V0(real X, real Y, real Z,
00190                   real& GammaX, real& GammaY, real& GammaZ) const throw();
00191 
00192     /**
00193      * Evaluate the centrifugal acceleration in geocentric coordinates.
00194      *
00195      * @param[in] X geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00196      * @param[in] Y geocentric coordinate of point (meters).
00197      * @param[out] fX the \e X component of the centrifugal acceleration
00198      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00199      * @param[out] fY the \e Y component of the centrifugal acceleration
00200      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00201      * @return \e Phi the centrifugal potential (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00202      *
00203      * \e Phi is independent of \e Z, thus \e fZ = 0.  This function
00204      * NormalGravity::U sums the results of NormalGravity::V0 and
00205      * NormalGravity::Phi.
00206      **********************************************************************/
00207     Math::real Phi(real X, real Y, real& fX, real& fY) const throw();
00208     ///@}
00209 
00210     /** \name Inspector functions
00211      **********************************************************************/
00212     ///@{
00213     /**
00214      * @return true if the object has been initialized.
00215      **********************************************************************/
00216     bool Init() const throw() { return _a > 0; }
00217 
00218     /**
00219      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00220      *   the value used in the constructor.
00221      **********************************************************************/
00222     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw()
00223     { return Init() ? _a : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00224 
00225     /**
00226      * @return \e GM the mass constant of the ellipsoid
00227      *   (m<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).  This is the value used in the
00228      *   constructor.
00229      **********************************************************************/
00230     Math::real MassConstant() const throw()
00231     { return Init() ? _GM : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00232 
00233     /**
00234      * @return \e J<sub>n</sub> the dynamical form factors of the ellipsoid.
00235      *
00236      * If \e n = 2 (the default), this is the value of <i>J</i><sub>2</sub>
00237      * used in the constructor.  Otherwise it is the zonal coefficient of the
00238      * Legendre harmonic sum of the normal gravitational potential.  Note that
00239      * \e J<sub>n</sub> = 0 if \e is odd.  In most gravity applications, fully
00240      * normalized Legendre functions are used and the corresponding coefficient
00241      * is <i>C</i><sub><i>n</i>0</sub> = -\e J<sub>n</sub> / sqrt(2 \e n + 1).
00242      **********************************************************************/
00243     Math::real DynamicalFormFactor(int n = 2) const throw()
00244     { return Init() ? ( n == 2 ? _J2 : Jn(n)) : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00245 
00246     /**
00247      * @return \e omega the angular velocity of the ellipsoid
00248      *   (rad s<sup>-1</sup>).  This is the value used in the constructor.
00249      **********************************************************************/
00250     Math::real AngularVelocity() const throw()
00251     { return Init() ? _omega : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00252 
00253     /**
00254      * @return <i>f</i> the flattening of the ellipsoid (\e a - \e b)/\e a.
00255      **********************************************************************/
00256     Math::real Flattening() const throw()
00257     { return Init() ? _f : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00258 
00259     /**
00260      * @return <i>gamma</i><sub>e</sub> the normal gravity at equator
00261      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00262      **********************************************************************/
00263     Math::real EquatorialGravity() const throw()
00264     { return Init() ? _gammae : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00265 
00266     /**
00267      * @return <i>gamma</i><sub>p</sub> the normal gravity at poles
00268      *   (m s<sup>-2</sup>).
00269      **********************************************************************/
00270     Math::real PolarGravity() const throw()
00271     { return Init() ? _gammap : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00272 
00273     /**
00274      * @return <i>f*</i> the gravity flattening
00275      *   (<i>gamma</i><sub>p</sub> - <i>gamma</i><sub>e</sub>) /
00276      *   <i>gamma</i><sub>e</sub>.
00277      **********************************************************************/
00278     Math::real GravityFlattening() const throw()
00279     { return Init() ? _fstar : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00280 
00281     /**
00282      * @return <i>U</i><sub>0</sub> the constant normal potential for the
00283      *   surface of the ellipsoid (m<sup>2</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>).
00284      **********************************************************************/
00285     Math::real SurfacePotential() const throw()
00286     { return Init() ? _U0 : Math::NaN<real>(); }
00287 
00288     /**
00289      * @return the Geocentric object used by this instance.
00290      **********************************************************************/
00291     const Geocentric& Earth() const throw() { return _earth; }
00292     ///@}
00293 
00294     /**
00295      * A global instantiation of NormalGravity for the WGS84 ellipsoid.
00296      **********************************************************************/
00297     static const NormalGravity WGS84;
00298 
00299     /**
00300      * A global instantiation of NormalGravity for the GRS80 ellipsoid.
00301      **********************************************************************/
00302     static const NormalGravity GRS80;
00303   };
00304 
00305 } // namespace GeographicLib
